title: China Eximbank provides $50 million loan to Black Sea Trade Development Bank for on-lending purposes
description: In 2021, China Eximbank and the Black Sea Trade Development Bank signed a $50 million loan agreement for on-lending purposes. The loan carried a 3-year maturity and an unknown interest rate.
combined_text:
# Sector
BANKING AND FINANCIAL SERVICES

# Title
China Eximbank provides $50 million loan to Black Sea Trade Development Bank for on-lending purposes

# Description
In 2021, China Eximbank and the Black Sea Trade Development Bank signed a $50 million loan agreement for on-lending purposes. The loan carried a 3-year maturity and an unknown interest rate.
justification: Project involves financial services with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Loan agreement for on-lending purposes, no specific project details provided

title: Chinese Government provides 17 hospital beds worth USD $12,558.44 to Fiji Ministry of Health and Medical Services for COVID-19 response at Nakasi Health Centre
description: On May 18, 2021, the Chinese Government provided 17 hospital beds to the Fiji Ministry of Health and Medical Services. This donation is valued at USD $12,558.44. The Health Ministry stated that they will use the beds to equip the Nakasi Health Centre, a medical facility that has been converted into Fiji’s sixth isolation ward in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government provides 17 hospital beds worth USD $12,558.44 to Fiji Ministry of Health and Medical Services for COVID-19 response at Nakasi Health Centre

# Description
On May 18, 2021, the Chinese Government provided 17 hospital beds to the Fiji Ministry of Health and Medical Services. This donation is valued at USD $12,558.44. The Health Ministry stated that they will use the beds to equip the Nakasi Health Centre, a medical facility that has been converted into Fiji’s sixth isolation ward in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare infrastructure without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Donation of hospital beds for COVID-19 response, healthcare sector focus

title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Fiji between January and December 2021 (Linked to Project ID#95365, 62721, 62576, 62719, 49134, 40003, and 64738)
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, as part of the DSSI, China Eximbank and the Government of Fiji signed a debt suspension agreement ('EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative II') on May 13, 2021.  Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between January 1, 2021 and June 30, 2021 under six government concessional loan agreements for the E-Government Project, the Low Cost Housing Project, the Fiji Public Rental Housing Project, the Buca Bay Moto Road Project, the Sigatoka Sawani Road Project, and the Nabouwalu Dreketi Road Project (captured via Project ID#62721, 62576, 62719, 49134, 40003, and 64738).   Then, on April 11, 2022, China Eximbank and the Government of Fiji signed another debt suspension agreement ('EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative III').  Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between July 1, 2021 and December 31, 2021 under the same six government concessional loan agreements for the E-Government Project, the Low Cost Housing Project, the Fiji Public Rental Housing Project, the Buca Bay Moto Road Project, the Sigatoka Sawani Road Project, and the Nabouwalu Dreketi Road Project.  The total (combined) value of the 'EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative II' suspension amount and the 'EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative III' suspension amount was RMB 143.8 million ($45.2 million).   Under the terms of the 'EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative II' debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower agreed that the repayment of the suspension amount for each loan agreement would take place during a 5.25-year repayment period after a 0.5-year grace period (starting from and including the repayment date/repayment date of principal and interest falling within the suspension period). Under the terms of the 'EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative III' debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower agreed that the repayment of the suspension amount for each loan agreement would take place during a 5.25-year repayment period and without a grace period. The final repayment date for the 'EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative II' suspension amount and the 'EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative III' suspension amount was identified as March 21, 2027.    At the time that the parties signed each debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that "[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement."  The borrower also agreed that: (1) "it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]"; (2) "it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]" and "work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system";  (3) "it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information"; and (4) "it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI."  The borrower began making principal and interest payments on the 'EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative II' suspension amount in 2022 and 2023. The suspension amount outstanding was RMB  57,392,966.29 (FJD 17,900,061.22) as of June 30, 2023. The borrower made principal payments worth RMB 14,513,913.54 (FJD 4,715,773.08) and interest payments worth RMB 1,385,139.27 (FJD 450,005.23) between July 1, 2022 and June 30, 2023.   The borrower began making principal and interest payments on the 'EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative III' suspension amount in 2022 and 2023. The suspension amount outstanding was RMB  64,220,042.96 (FJD 20,029,330.68) as of June 30, 2023. The borrower made principal payments worth RMB 7,300,034.66 (FJD 2,375,772.01) and interest payments worth RMB 1,450,268.24 (FJD 471,205.45) between July 1, 2022 and June 30, 2023.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of Fiji. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0,  https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0, and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0. 2. The total estimated suspension amount is based on reporting from the Government of Fiji (via https://www.economy.gov.fj/images/Treasury/uploads/Debt/Debt_Report_-_Q3_2021_FINAL_PSE_Approved.pdf). It is not based on the size of the debt service deferral — $22,241,000 ($18,271,000 in principal payments and $3,970,000 in interest payments) — that the Government of Fiji secured from the Chinese Government in 2021 (as recorded by the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System on December 6, 2022). The discrepancy between these two figures merits further investigation.3. The data on amounts outstanding and repayments were provided by Fiji's Ministry of Finance to AidData's Executive Director in June 2023. See https://www.dropbox.com/s/jqsnza05ar9r8x3/Data%20on%20data%20on%20disbursements%2C%20repayments%20and%20amounts%20outstanding%20under%20China%20Eximbank%20loans.pdf?dl=04.  The 'EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative I' debt suspension agreement is captured via Project ID#95365.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Fiji between January and December 2021 (Linked to Project ID#95365, 62721, 62576, 62719, 49134, 40003, and 64738)

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, as part of the DSSI, China Eximbank and the Government of Fiji signed a debt suspension agreement ('EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative II') on May 13, 2021.  Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between January 1, 2021 and June 30, 2021 under six government concessional loan agreements for the E-Government Project, the Low Cost Housing Project, the Fiji Public Rental Housing Project, the Buca Bay Moto Road Project, the Sigatoka Sawani Road Project, and the Nabouwalu Dreketi Road Project (captured via Project ID#62721, 62576, 62719, 49134, 40003, and 64738).   Then, on April 11, 2022, China Eximbank and the Government of Fiji signed another debt suspension agreement ('EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative III').  Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between July 1, 2021 and December 31, 2021 under the same six government concessional loan agreements for the E-Government Project, the Low Cost Housing Project, the Fiji Public Rental Housing Project, the Buca Bay Moto Road Project, the Sigatoka Sawani Road Project, and the Nabouwalu Dreketi Road Project.  The total (combined) value of the 'EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative II' suspension amount and the 'EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative III' suspension amount was RMB 143.8 million ($45.2 million).   Under the terms of the 'EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative II' debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower agreed that the repayment of the suspension amount for each loan agreement would take place during a 5.25-year repayment period after a 0.5-year grace period (starting from and including the repayment date/repayment date of principal and interest falling within the suspension period). The final repayment date for the 'EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative II' suspension amount and the 'EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative III' suspension amount was identified as March 21, 2027.    At the time that the parties signed each debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that "[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement."  The borrower also agreed that: (1) "it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]"; (2) "it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]" and "work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system";  (3) "it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information"; and (4) "it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI."  The borrower began making principal and interest payments on the 'EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative II' suspension amount in 2022 and 2023. The suspension amount outstanding was RMB  57,392,966.29 (FJD 17,900,061.22) as of June 30, 2023. The borrower made principal payments worth RMB 14,513,913.54 (FJD 4,715,773.08) and interest payments worth RMB 1,385,139.27 (FJD 450,005.23) between July 1, 2022 and June 30, 2023.   The borrower began making principal and interest payments on the 'EXIM China Debt Service Suspension Initiative III' suspension amount in 2022 and 2023. The suspension amount outstanding was RMB  64,220,042.96 (FJD 20,029,330.68) as of June 30, 2023. The borrower made principal payments worth RMB 7,300,034.66 (FJD 2,375,772.01) and interest payments worth RMB 1,450,268.24 (FJD 471,205.45) between July 1, 2022 and June 30, 2023.
justification: The project involves debt service suspension agreements, which are financial arrangements without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Debt service suspension initiative, financial terms and repayment schedules, no direct environmental or energy-related activities

title: Chinese Embassy provides funding for Malawai Outdoor Volleyball Court in March 2021
description: On March 12, 2021, an official handover ceremony was held for the Chinese-funded Malawai Outdoor Volleyball Court. The court is located in Nadi, Fiji and its construction was fully funded by the Chinese Embassy.  China Civil Engineering Group South Pacific (Fiji) Co., Ltd. constructed the court and it was completed in December of 2020.  The facility is intended for sports like volleyball, badminton, and other wellness programs.   China’s Ambassador to Fiji, Qian Bo, and Fiji’s Minister of Employment, Youth, and Sports Affairs, Parveen Kumar Bala, attended the ceremony. 100 people from the Fiji Youth and Sports Department,  government officials from the Western District, some diplomats from the embassy, ​​employees of China Civil Engineering Group South Pacific (Fiji) Co., Ltd., and people from the community also attended the event.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Embassy provides funding for Malawai Outdoor Volleyball Court in March 2021

# Description
On March 12, 2021, an official handover ceremony was held for the Chinese-funded Malawai Outdoor Volleyball Court. The court is located in Nadi, Fiji and its construction was fully funded by the Chinese Embassy.  China Civil Engineering Group South Pacific (Fiji) Co., Ltd. constructed the court and it was completed in December of 2020.  The facility is intended for sports like volleyball, badminton, and other wellness programs.   China’s Ambassador to Fiji, Qian Bo, and Fiji’s Minister of Employment, Youth, and Sports Affairs, Parveen Kumar Bala, attended the ceremony. 100 people from the Fiji Youth and Sports Department,  government officials from the Western District, some diplomats from the embassy, ​​employees of China Civil Engineering Group South Pacific (Fiji) Co., Ltd., and people from the community also attended the event.
justification: Project is a sports facility with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Outdoor volleyball court construction, intended for sports and wellness programs

title: Chinese Government provides USD $3,604.91 worth of anti-epidemic supplies to Fiji in October 2021
description: On October 11, 2021, the Chinese Government provided anti-epidemic supplies to Fiji. The supplies included ventilators, protective clothing, N95 masks, medical masks, face shields, medical gloves, hats, shoe covers, and other supplies. These supplies are valued at USD $3,604.91. This donation was made to support anti-epidemic efforts in Fiji.   A handover ceremony was held for this donation in Suva, the capital of Fiji. China’s Ambassador to Fiji, Qian Bo, and Fiji’s Minister of Health, Waka Inabate, attended the ceremony.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government provides USD $3,604.91 worth of anti-epidemic supplies to Fiji in October 2021

# Description
On October 11, 2021, the Chinese Government provided anti-epidemic supplies to Fiji. The supplies included ventilators, protective clothing, N95 masks, medical masks, face shields, medical gloves, hats, shoe covers, and other supplies. These supplies are valued at USD $3,604.91. This donation was made to support anti-epidemic efforts in Fiji.   A handover ceremony was held for this donation in Suva, the capital of Fiji. China’s Ambassador to Fiji, Qian Bo, and Fiji’s Minister of Health, Waka Inabate, attended the ceremony.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies for public health purposes with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Anti-epidemic supplies including ventilators, protective equipment, and medical supplies for healthcare purposes

title: Chinese Ministry of Public Security provides police supplies to Fiji Police in April 2021
description: On April 15, 2021, the Chinese Ministry of Public Security donated a batch of police supplies to the Fiji Police. The donation included police vehicles, inspire drones, vehicle conference systems, and servers that connect CCTV cameras to the police monitoring network. This donation was made to support Fiji’s law enforcement capabilities. The monetary value of this donation is USD $730,357.32.   A handover ceremony was held for this donation. China’s Ambassador to Fiji, Qian Bo, Fiji’s Minister of Defense, National Security and Police, Serui Ratu, and the Acting Superintendent of the Fiji Police attended the ceremony. About 80 other officials from Fiji’s Ministry of Defense, Police Headquarters, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and diplomats from the Chinese Embassy also attended the event. Following the handover ceremony, Ambassador Qian signed the material handover certificate with Minister Serui Ratu.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Ministry of Public Security provides police supplies to Fiji Police in April 2021

# Description
On April 15, 2021, the Chinese Ministry of Public Security donated a batch of police supplies to the Fiji Police. The donation included police vehicles, inspire drones, vehicle conference systems, and servers that connect CCTV cameras to the police monitoring network. This donation was made to support Fiji’s law enforcement capabilities. The monetary value of this donation is USD $730,357.32.   A handover ceremony was held for this donation. China’s Ambassador to Fiji, Qian Bo, Fiji’s Minister of Defense, National Security and Police, Serui Ratu, and the Acting Superintendent of the Fiji Police attended the ceremony. About 80 other officials from Fiji’s Ministry of Defense, Police Headquarters, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and diplomats from the Chinese Embassy also attended the event. Following the handover ceremony, Ambassador Qian signed the material handover certificate with Minister Serui Ratu.
justification: Project focuses on law enforcement support without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of police supplies including vehicles, drones, and surveillance equipment for law enforcement purposes

title: Chinese Government provides USD $500,000 hurricane relief grant to Fiji Government in March 2021
description: On March 30, 2021, the Chinese Government provided a USD $500,000 (FJD 1 million) grant  to the Fiji Government to support cyclone recovery efforts. Tropical cyclones “Yasa” and “Ana” affected Fiji in early 2021, prompting aid donations from the Chinese Government. It is expected that 60% of the grant will be allotted to the Ministry of Education, 20% to the Ministry of Agriculture, and 20% to the Ministry of Fisheries since these three sectors were most affected by the tropical cyclones. This was the second batch of funding from the Chinese government meant to support Fiji's post-hurricane reconstruction work.   A handover ceremony was held for this donation. China’s Ambassador Qian Bo handed over emergency aid from the Chinese Government to Prime Minister Voreqe Bainimarama of Fiji.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Government provides USD $500,000 hurricane relief grant to Fiji Government in March 2021

# Description
On March 30, 2021, the Chinese Government provided a USD $500,000 (FJD 1 million) grant  to the Fiji Government to support cyclone recovery efforts. Tropical cyclones “Yasa” and “Ana” affected Fiji in early 2021, prompting aid donations from the Chinese Government. It is expected that 60% of the grant will be allotted to the Ministry of Education, 20% to the Ministry of Agriculture, and 20% to the Ministry of Fisheries since these three sectors were most affected by the tropical cyclones. This was the second batch of funding from the Chinese government meant to support Fiji's post-hurricane reconstruction work.   A handover ceremony was held for this donation. China’s Ambassador Qian Bo handed over emergency aid from the Chinese Government to Prime Minister Voreqe Bainimarama of Fiji.
justification: Project is humanitarian aid for disaster relief without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Hurricane relief grant, funding allocated to education, agriculture, and fisheries sectors affected by cyclones

title: Chinese Defense Attaché provides soccer supplies to Fiji Army football team in November 2021
description: On November 23, 2021, the Chinese Defense Attaché, Senior Colonel Yu Ke, donated soccer supplies to the Fiji Army football team. The supplies included soccer balls, carry bags, water bottles, training cones, whistles, and goalkeeper gloves. This donation was made to support the football team as they returned to regularly scheduled games after a three year hiatus. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation. At the ceremony, Fiji Army Football President, Lieutenant Alfaaz Mohammed, thanked Chinese Defense Attaché Yu Ke for the donation.
combined_text:

This donation was made to support the football team as they returned to regularly scheduled games after a three year hiatus. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation. At the ceremony, Fiji Army Football President, Lieutenant Alfaaz Mohammed, thanked Chinese Defense Attaché Yu Ke for the donation.
justification: Project involves donation of sports equipment with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of soccer supplies to support sports activities, no energy or industrial components

title: Chinese Defense Attaché provides COVID-19 supplies to the Fiji Military Forces in December 2021
description: On December 14, 2021, the Chinese Defense Attaché provided a donation of masks, hand sanitizers, food, and other supplies to the Republic of Fiji Military Forces. This donation was made to support Fiji’s COVID-19 response efforts. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation. The Defence Attaché for the People's Liberation Army (PLA) of the People's Republic of China, Senior Colonel Yu Ke, presented the batch of supplies to the Republic of Fiji Military Forces (RFMF). Commander of Land Forces, Colonel Onisimo Covunisaqa, also attended the ceremony and thanked the Chinese DA for the timely assistance.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Defense Attaché provides COVID-19 supplies to the Fiji Military Forces in December 2021

# Description
On December 14, 2021, the Chinese Defense Attaché provided a donation of masks, hand sanitizers, food, and other supplies to the Republic of Fiji Military Forces. This donation was made to support Fiji’s COVID-19 response efforts. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation. The Defence Attaché for the People's Liberation Army (PLA) of the People's Republic of China, Senior Colonel Yu Ke, presented the batch of supplies to the Republic of Fiji Military Forces (RFMF). Commander of Land Forces, Colonel Onisimo Covunisaqa, also attended the ceremony and thanked the Chinese DA for the timely assistance.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare support and social development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of masks, hand sanitizers, food, and other supplies for COVID-19 response

title: Chinese Embassy and Guangzhou Municipality jointly provide COVID-19 materials worth USD $225,004.15 to Fiji in June 2021
description: On June 10, 2021, the Chinese Embassy and the Guangzhou Municipality jointly provided COVID-19 materials to Fiji. The materials included 550,000 surgical masks, 2,000 gowns, and 200 thermal guns. The monetary value of this donation is USD $225,004.15. This donation was made to support Fiji’s COVID-19 response efforts.
